abstract: Micropipette recording with juxtacellular Neurobiotin ejection, linked micropipette-microwire recording, and antidromic and orthodromic activation from the ventral tegmental area and locus coeruleus were used to identify hypocretin (Hcrt) cells in anesthetized rats and develop criteria for identification of these cells in unanesthetized, unrestrained animals. We found that Hcrt cells have broad action potentials with elongated later positive deflections that distinguish them from adjacent antidromically identified cells. They are relatively inactive in quiet waking but are transiently activated during sensory stimulation. Hcrt cells are silent in slow wave sleep and tonic periods of REM sleep, with occasional burst discharge in phasic REM. Hcrt cells discharge in active waking and have moderate and approximately equal levels of activity during grooming and eating and maximal activity during exploratory behavior. Our findings suggest that these cells are activated during emotional and sensorimotor conditions similar to those that trigger cataplexy in narcoleptic animals.

Progressive kidney failure is a genetically and clinically heterogeneous group of disorders. Podocyte foot processes and the interposed glomerular slit diaphragm are essential components of the permeability barrier in the kidney. Mutations in genes encoding structural proteins of the podocyte lead to the development of proteinuria, resulting in progressive kidney failure and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. Here, we show that the canonical transient receptor potential 6 (TRPC6) ion channel is expressed in podocytes and is a component of the glomerular slit diaphragm. We identified five families with autosomal dominant focal segmental glomerulosclerosis in which disease segregated with mutations in the gene TRPC6 on chromosome 11q. Two of the TRPC6 mutants had increased current amplitudes. These data show that TRPC6 channel activity at the slit diaphragm is essential for proper regulation of podocyte structure and function.

Increased epithelial permeability is observed in inflammatory states. However, the mechanism by which inflammatory mediators such as IFN-gamma increase epithelial permeability is unknown. We recently observed that IFN-gamma induces disassembly of tight junctions (TJ); in this study we asked whether such TJ disassembly is mediated by endocytosis of junctional proteins. The role of three major internalization pathways in disruption of TJ in IFN-gamma-treated intestinal epithelial cells was analyzed using selective inhibitors and markers of the pathways. No role for the clathrin- and caveolar-mediated endocytosis in the IFN-gamma-induced internalization of TJ proteins was observed. However, inhibitors of macropinocytosis blocked internalization of TJ proteins and junctional proteins colocalized with macropinocytosis markers, dextran and phosphatidylinositol-3,4,5-trisphosphate. Internalized TJ proteins were identified in early and recycling endosomes but not in late endosomes/lysosomes. These results for the first time suggest that IFN-gamma produces a leaky epithelial barrier by inducing macropinoytosis of TJ proteins.

There are currently no noninvasive imaging methods available for auditory brain mapping in mice, despite the increasing use of genetically engineered mice to study auditory brain development and hearing loss. We developed a manganese-enhanced MRI (MEMRI) method to map regions of accumulated sound-evoked activity in awake, normally behaving mice. To demonstrate its utility for high-resolution (100-microm) brain mapping, we used MEMRI to show the tonotopic organization of the mouse inferior colliculus. To test its efficacy in an experimental setting, we acquired data from mice experiencing unilateral conductive hearing loss at different ages. Larger and persistent changes in auditory brainstem activity resulted when hearing loss occurred before the onset of hearing, showing that early hearing loss biases the response toward the functional ear. Thus, MEMRI provides a sensitive and effective method for mapping the mouse auditory brainstem and has great potential for a range of functional neuroimaging studies in normal and mutant mice.

We recently reported that cultivation of oat (Avena sativa L.) without phosphate resulted in plasma membrane phosphoglycerolipids being replaced to a large extent by digalactosyldiacylglycerol (DGDG) (Andersson, M. X., Stridh, M. H., Larsson, K. E., Liljenberg, C., and Sandelius, A. S. (2003) FEBS Lett. 537, 128–132). We report here that DGDG is not the only non-phosphorous-containing lipid that replaces phospholipids but that also the content of glucosylceramides and sterolglycosides increased in plasma membranes as a response to phosphate starvation. In addition, phosphate deficiency induced similar changes in lipid composition in the tonoplast. The phospholipid-to-glycolipid replacement apparently did not occur to any greater extent in endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, or mitochondrial inner membranes. In contrast to the marked effects on lipid composition, the polypeptide patterns were largely similar between root plasma membranes from well-fertilized and phosphate-limited oat, although the latter condition induced at least four polypeptides, including a chaperone of the HSP80 or HSP90 family, a phosphate transporter, and a bacterial-type phosphoesterase. The latter polypeptide reacted with an antibody raised against a phosphate deficiency-induced phospholipase C from Arabidopsis thaliana (Nakamura, Y., Awai, K., Masuda, T., Yoshioka, Y., Takamiya, K., and Ohta, H. (2005) J. Biol. Chem. 280, 7469–7476). In plasma membranes from oat, however, a phospholipase D-type activity and a phosphatidic acid phosphatase were the dominant lipase activities induced by phosphate deficiency. Our results reflect a highly developed plasticity in the lipid composition of the plasma membrane and the tonoplast. In addition, phosphate deficiency-induced alterations in plasma membrane lipid composition may involve different sets of lipid-metabolizing enzymes in different plant tissues or species, at different stages of plant development and/or at different stages of stress adjustments. X., Stridh, M. H., Larsson, K. E., Liljenberg, C., and Sandelius, A. S. (2003) FEBS Lett. 537, 128–132). We report here that DGDG is not the only non-phosphorous-containing lipid that replaces phospholipids but that also the content of glucosylceramides and sterolglycosides increased in plasma membranes as a response to phosphate starvation. In addition, phosphate deficiency induced similar changes in lipid composition in the tonoplast. (2005) J. Biol. Chem. 280, 7469–7476). In plasma membranes from oat, however, a phospholipase D-type activity and a phosphatidic acid phosphatase were the dominant lipase activities induced by phosphate deficiency. Our results reflect a highly developed plasticity in the lipid composition of the plasma membrane and the tonoplast. In addition, phosphate deficiency-induced alterations in plasma membrane lipid composition may involve different sets of lipid-metabolizing enzymes in different plant tissues or species, at different stages of plant development and/or at different stages of stress adjustments. Phosphate is often a limiting plant nutrient, and the effects of a limited supply have been extensively characterized on several levels, such as growth, root architecture, and metabolism of water-soluble phosphate-containing metabolites (1Raghothama K.G. Ann. Rev. Plant Physiol. Mol. Biol. 1999; 50: 665-693Crossref PubMed Scopus (1350) Google Scholar, 2Vance C.P. Uhde-Stone C. Allan D.L. New Phytol. 2003; 157: 423-447Crossref Scopus (1834) Google Scholar). For bacteria, it is well established that membrane phospholipids can function as a phosphate reserve and be replaced by glycolipids during phosphate starvation (3Minnikin D.E. Abdolrahimzadeh H. Baddiley J. Nature. 1974; 249: 268-269Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar, 4Benning C. Huang Z.H. Gage D.A. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1995; 317: 103-111Crossref PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar, 5Lopez-Lara I.M. Sohlenkamp C. Geiger O. Mol. Plant-Microbe Interact. 2003; 16: 567-579Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar). The corresponding function for plant phospholipids, as a phosphate reserve, was realized much later. When cultivated under phosphate-limited conditions, the decrease in tissue phospholipids was compensated for by an increase in the glycolipid digalactosyldiacylglycerol (DGDG), 1The abbreviations used are: DGDG, digalactosyldiacylglycerol; 16:0, hexadecanoic acid; 18:2, all-cis-9,12-octadecadienoic acid; GlcCer, glucosylceramide; MGDG, monogalactosyldiacylglycerol; NPC4, Arabidopsis thaliana non-specific phospholipase C; PA, phosphatidic acid; PC, phosphatidylcholine; PE, phosphatidylethanolamine; PLC, phospholipase C; PLD, phospholipase D; SG, sterol glucoside; MALDI-TOF, matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight; DAG, diacylglycerol; LC-FTISR; liquid chromatography Fourier transform ion spectrometry. 1The abbreviations used are: DGDG, digalactosyldiacylglycerol; 16:0, hexadecanoic acid; 18:2, all-cis-9,12-octadecadienoic acid; GlcCer, glucosylceramide; MGDG, monogalactosyldiacylglycerol; NPC4, Arabidopsis thaliana non-specific phospholipase C; PA, phosphatidic acid; PC, phosphatidylcholine; PE, phosphatidylethanolamine; PLC, phospholipase C; PLD, phospholipase D; SG, sterol glucoside; MALDI-TOF, matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight; DAG, diacylglycerol; LC-FTISR; liquid chromatography Fourier transform ion spectrometry. as reported for Arabidopsis thaliana (6Hartel H. Benning C. Biochem. Soc. Trans. 2000; 28: 729-732Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 7Hartel H. Dörmann P. Benning C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 10649-10654Crossref PubMed Scopus (284) Google Scholar, 8Hartel H. Dörmann P. Benning C. J. Photochem. Photobiol. 2001; 61: 46-51Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar), shoots and roots of oat seedlings (Avena sativa) (9Andersson M.X. Stridh M.H. Larsson K.E. Liljenberg C. Sandelius A.S. FEBS Lett. 2003; 537: 128-132Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar), and Acer platanus suspension cells (10Jouhet J. Maréchal E. Bligny R. Joyard J. Block M.A. FEBS Lett. 2003; 544: 63-68Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). The only non-plastid membrane of very high fraction purity that has been repeatedly reported to contain galactolipids, especially DGDG, is the plasma membrane. Except for a few reports (11Liljenberg C. Kates M. Can. J. Cell Biol. 1984; 63: 77-84Crossref Scopus (58) Google Scholar, 12Rochester C.P. Kjellbom P. Larsson C. Physiol. Plant. 1987; 71: 257-263Crossref Scopus (53) Google Scholar, 13Norberg P. Liljenberg C. Plant Physiol. 1991; 96: 1136-1141Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar), the content of 1–5 mol% DGDG has been ascribed to plastid contamination. We recently established that DGDG indeed is a plasma membrane constituent because it was the dominant acyl lipid of plasma membranes isolated from shoots and roots of oat that had been cultivated for 4 weeks in a phosphate-free medium (9Andersson M.X. Stridh M.H. Larsson K.E. Liljenberg C. Sandelius A.S. FEBS Lett. 2003; 537: 128-132Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar). Our aim with the present study was to characterize in more detail the alterations in plasma membrane composition that occurred as a result of phosphate limitation and to establish whether the lipid replacement in extra-plastidial membranes also occurred in other membranes. Materials—Polyethylene glycol 3350 (Ultra) and lipid standards were from Sigma. TLC plates, organic solvents, inorganic salts, and other chemicals were from Merck. Radiolabeled phosphatidic acid (PA) was from PerkinElmer Life Sciences. Other radiochemicals and Dextran T500 were from Amersham Biosciences. Plant Material—Grains of oat (A. sativa L. cv. Vital) were soaked in deionized water overnight and sown on and covered with vermiculite. The plants were grown in a full nutrient solution (13Norberg P. Liljenberg C. Plant Physiol. 1991; 96: 1136-1141Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar) or in a nutrient solution in which KH2PO4 was replaced with KCl, in a climate chamber with a 16-h light/8-h dark period. The temperature was 20 °C/17 °C and the relative humidity was 70%/80% during the light/dark periods. Isolation of a Microsomal Membrane Fraction—Oat roots, 35–40 g, were homogenized with a kitchen blender equipped with replaceable razor blades in 2 ml·g–1 of 50 mm Hepes/KOH, pH 7.5, 0.40 m sucrose, 10 mm KCl, 3.0 mm EGTA, 3.0 mm NaEDTA, 10 mm ascorbic acid, 0.1% (w/v) bovine serum albumin, and 2.0 mm dithiothreitol. The homogenate was filtered through one layer of Miracloth™ (Chicopee Mills), and the filtrate was centrifuged for 10 min at 6000 × gmax (fixed angle rotor). The supernatant was centrifuged for 30 min at 60,000 × gmax (fixed angle rotor). The pellet was suspended in 5.0 mm potassium Pi, pH 7.8, 2.0 mm KCl, and 0.25 m sucrose. Isolation of Oat Root Plasma Membrane—Plasma membranes were isolated from oat root microsomal membranes by aqueous polymer two-phase partitioning. To obtain plasma membrane fractions of very high and essentially equal fraction purity, higher polymer concentrations were required for the oat membranes from phosphate-limited plants than for the membranes from fully fertilized plants. Thus, the 20.00-g two-phase systems used for microsomal membranes from 30–40 g of oat root tissue contained 6.2% (w/w) each of Dextran T500 and polyethylene glycol 3350 for membranes from well-fertilized tissue but 6.6% (w/w) of each polymer for membranes from phosphate-limited material. The systems also contained 5.0 mmol·kg–1 potassium Pi, pH 7.8, 2.0 mmol·kg–1 KCl, and 0.25 mol·kg–1 sucrose. After a three-step two-phase partition (14Sandelius A.S. Morré D.J. Larsson C. Moller I.M. The Plant Plasma Membrane. Springer Verlag, Berlin1990: 44-75Crossref Google Scholar), the plasma membrane-rich upper phase was diluted with 10 mm HEPES/KOH, pH 7.5, 0.25 m sucrose, and 10 mm KCl; pelleted twice at 100,000 × gmax for 30 min; and resuspended in the same buffer. Aliquots of the suspended membranes were used for immediate lipid extraction or frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at –80 °C until further analysis. The difference in two-phase compositions, compared with the earlier work (9Andersson M.X. Stridh M.H. Larsson K.E. Liljenberg C. Sandelius A.S. FEBS Lett. 2003; 537: 128-132Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar), was due to different batches of polymers. The purified plasma membranes were essentially devoid of contaminating membranes (data not shown; cf. Figs. 2, 3, and 5 below).Fig. 3The polypeptide patterns of membrane fractions obtained from well-fertilized and phosphate-limited oat. Silver-stained SDS gels are shown for root membrane polypeptides from well-fertilized (A) and phosphate-limited (B) oat. Polypeptides identified by MALDI-TOF or nano-LC-FTISR are indicated. C, distribution of V-type ATPase (triangles) and P-type ATPase (circles) among the 10 fractions. Filled symbols denote well-fertilized oat, and open symbols denote oat grown under phosphate-limited conditions. Otherwise the figure is as described in the Fig. 2 legend.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Fig. 5Effects of phosphate limitation on the polypeptide composition of oat root plasma membranes. Plasma membranes were isolated from oat roots grown without (–P) or with (+P) phosphate for 4 weeks. The polypeptides were separated by 10–20% gradient SDS-PAGE and visualized by silver staining. The numbers to the right denote the molecular masses (in kDa) of the standard peptides. The polypeptide bands indicated to the left were cut out and subjected to in-gel trypsin digestion followed by nano-LC-FTISR.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Fractionation of Oat Root Membranes—The microsomes were also fractionated by aqueous polymer two-phase partition in a 10-step hand counter-current procedure (Fig. 1) (15Larsson C. Hall J.L. Moore A.L. Isolation of Membranes and Organelles from Plant Cells. Academic Press, London1983: 277-309Google Scholar, 16Sandelius A.S. Hellgren L.I. Quinn P.J. Harwood J.L. Plant Lipid Biochemistry, Structure and Utilisation. Portland Press Ltd., London1990: 257-259Google Scholar). The 10 systems each weighed 10.00 g and contained 5.0 mmol·kg–1 potassium Pi, pH 7.8, 0.25 mol·kg–1 sucrose, Dextran T500, and polyethylene glycol 3350. For microsomes isolated from control roots, the systems contained 6.2% (w/w) of each polymer, whereas for microsomes from roots of phosphate-limited oat, the systems contained 6.4% (w/w) of each polymer. The membrane sample was included in the first tube. After shaking and phase separation, the upper phase of the first tube was transferred to a fresh lower phase in tube 2, and fresh upper phase was added to the first tube. The procedure was repeated until upper phase had reached tube 10, and all tubes contained both upper and lower phase. All 10 complete two-phase systems were each diluted with 10 mm HEPES/KOH, pH 7.5, 0.25 m sucrose, and 10 mm KCl and pelleted twice at 100,000 × gmax. Lipid Analyses—Membrane lipids were extracted (17Sommarin M. Sandelius A.S. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1988; 958: 268-278Crossref Scopus (81) Google Scholar) and fractionated on Si60 solid phase extraction columns (Supelco, Bellefonte, PA). Briefly, the lipid extract was applied to a 100-mg Si60 column conditioned with 2.0 ml of chloroform:acetone (9:1, by volume). Non-polar lipids were eluted with 4.0 ml of chloroform:acetone (9:1, by volume), glycolipids were eluted with 2.0 ml of acetone:methanol (9:1, by volume), and finally, phospholipids were eluted with 2.0 ml of methanol. The separate fractions were taken to dryness under N2. Polar lipids were dissolved in chloroform:methanol (2:1, by volume), and the nonpolar lipids were dissolved in chloroform. To separate and quantify polar lipids, straight phase high pressure liquid chromatography (Hewlett Packard series 1050) was used. The lipids were separated on a Lichrosorb Si60 125 × 4-mm column (Merck) with a binary gradient system (18Becart J. Chevalier C. Biesse J. J. High Res. Chrom. 1990; 13: 126-129Crossref Scopus (138) Google Scholar). The lipids were detected with a Sedere 45 evaporative light scattering detector (Sedex, Vitry, France) operated at 50 °C with filtered air at 0.22 megapascal as nebulizer gas. All lipid classes were identified and quantified using retention times and calibration curves obtained with authentic lipid standards chromatographed under identical conditions. To analyze free sterols and fatty acid methyl esters, a Hewlett Packard 5890 series II gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector was used. The underivatized free sterols in the neutral lipid fraction were separated on a DB-5 capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm; J&W Scientific) with N2 as carrier gas at a constant flow of 2 ml·min–1. The injector and detector were maintained at 300 °C. The oven temperature was increased from 160 °C to 300 °C at 10 °C·min–1 and maintained at 300 °C for 10 min. β-Cholestanol was used as internal standard. Fatty acid methyl esters were produced by base-catalyzed methylation in 0.5 m sodium methoxide in methanol (19Christie W.W. Lipid Analysis. Pergamon Press, Oxford1976Google Scholar). Diheptadecanoylphosphatidylcholine (PC) was used as internal standard. The fatty acid methyl esters were separated on a DB-23 capillary column (60 m × 0.32 mm; J&W Scientific) using N2 at a constant flow of 2 ml·min–1 as carrier gas. The injector and detector were maintained at 230 °C throughout the analysis. The oven temperature was maintained at 150 °C for 2 min, increased to 170 °C at 50 °C·min–1, further increased to 210 °C at 2 °C·min–1, and maintained at 210 °C for 5 min. Protein Analysis—Membrane protein content was determined as described previously (20Smith P.K. Krohn R.I. Hermanson G.T. Mallia A.K. Gartner F.H. Provenzano M.D. Fujimoto E.K. Goeke N.M. Olson B.J. Klenk D.C. Anal. Biochem. 1985; 150: 76-85Crossref PubMed Scopus (18349) Google Scholar), except that the samples were pre-incubated in 0.10% (w/v) Triton X-100 prior to the addition of the reagent. Prior to SDS-PAGE, membrane fractions were incubated in 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 6.8, 10% (v/v) glycerol, 2% (w/v) SDS, and 50 mm dithiothreitol for 15 min at 60 °C. Polypeptides were separated on 10% (w/v) Tris-HCl SDS-PAGE precast 15 × 15-cm gels (Bio-Rad). After separation, the proteins were stained by Coomassie Brilliant Blue and after destaining, with Proteo Silver™ silver stain kit (Sigma). Specific bands (see Figs. 3 and 5) were excised from the gels and sent for identification by MALDI-TOF or nano-LC-FTISR spectroscopy (Swegene Proteomics Center, Göteborg University, Göteborg, Sweden). Each gel piece was washed three times with acetonitrile:aqueous 25 mm NH4HCO3 (1:1, by volume) and once with methanol:aqueous 25 mm NH4HCO3 (1:1, by volume) and vacuum-dried. The dry gel piece was incubated in 10 μg·ml–1 trypsin while shaking at 37 °C. The tryptic digest was eluted from the gel piece with acetonitrile:aqueous 2% (v/v) trifluoroacetic acid (75:25, by volume). 0.5 μl of this peptide solution was mixed with 0.5 μl of matrix solution (12 mg·ml–1 α-cyano-4-OH-cinnamic acid in acetonitrile:water; 1:1, by volume) directly on the matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization probe and allowed to dry at ambient conditions. Samples were analyzed using a matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-LR mass spectrometer (Micromass, Manchester, UK) in reflectron mode. ACTH (18–39) MH+ 2465.199 was used as external lock mass, and tryptic autodigest MH+ 2211.105 was used as internal lock mass. Monoisotopic mass values were used for peptide mass mapping using MASCOT (www.matrixscience.com), against the nr data base at National Center for Biotechnology Information. All identifications had a score above 100, well above the limit of 74 for the 95% level of confidence. When necessary, samples were purified and concentrated with Zip-Tips containing C18 resin (Millipore, Billerica, MA). The peptides eluted in 3.5 μl of 0.1% (v/v) formic acid in acetonitrile:water (1:1, by volume) analyzed by nano-LC-FTISR on a Thermo Finnigan LTQ-FT operated in data-dependent mode with pre-separation of the peptides on a C18 capillary column (21Olsen J.V. Ong S.E. Mann M. Mol. Cell. Proteomics. 2004; 3: 608-614Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (846) Google Scholar). The tandem mass spectrometry data were used as input for protein identification by MASCOT (www.matrixscience.com). No restrictions in species, molecular weight, or pI were applied when searching against the non-redundant data base of National Center for Biotechnology Information. Proteins identified all had a score exceeding 80, whereas 43 represents the 95% confidence level. For Western blot analyses, membrane fractions containing 10 μg of protein were denatured as described above and separated on 10% bis-Tris Novex™ ready gels (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer's instructions. The polypeptides were electroblotted onto nitrocellulose membranes (Bio-Rad), using a xCel II Blot Module (Invitrogen). The membranes were probed with an antibody raised against the C-terminal 120 amino acids of a putative phospholipase C of A. thaliana (NPC4) (22Nakamura Y. Awai K. Masuda T. Yoshioka Y. Takamiya K. Ohta H. J. Biol. Chem. 2005; 280: 7469-7476Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (186) Google Scholar) followed by an antirabbit horseradish peroxidase-linked secondary antibody from donkey (Amersham Biosciences). The peroxidase activity was detected by enhanced chemiluminescence using the SuperSignal West Dura Extended Duration Substrate (Pierce). Phospholipase Assays—The assays were essentially as described previously (22Nakamura Y. Awai K. Masuda T. Yoshioka Y. Takamiya K. Ohta H. J. Biol. Chem. 2005; 280: 7469-7476Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (186) Google Scholar). For each assay, 14 μg of unlabeled lipid and 12.5 nCi of radiolabeled lipid were dried under N2 and sonicated in 100 μl of 200 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.3, containing 0.25% (w/v) deoxycholate. The lipids used were soybean PC with 1–16:0, 2-[14C]18:2-PC (final specific activity, 0.70 mCi·mmol–1), soybean phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) with 1–16:0, 2-[14C]18:2-PE (final specific activity, 0.66 mCi·mmol–1), and egg PA with 1,2-[14C]16:0-PA (final specific activity, 0.57 mCi·mmol–1). Water, other additions, and membranes were added to a final volume of 200 μl. The assays were started by addition of membrane fractions, incubated with shaking at 37 °C, and stopped by addition of 750 μl of chloroform:methanol (1:2, by volume). The lipids were extracted by an acidic modification of the Bligh and Dyer procedure (17Sommarin M. Sandelius A.S. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1988; 958: 268-278Crossref Scopus (81) Google Scholar). TLC separations and analysis of lipid radiolabel were as described previously (23Andersson M.X. Kjellberg J.M. Sandelius A.S. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2004; 1684: 46-53Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). In the phospholipase assays, plasma membranes isolated from a new oat cultivar, Belinda, were used. We analyzed marker enzyme activities, lipid composition, and polypeptide pattern and found no differences between these plasma membranes and those obtained from the no longer available cultivar Vital with either fully fertilized or phosphate-deficient plants (data not shown). Phospholipase activities were also assayed in native gel-separated polypeptides. Root plasma membranes from phosphate-limited oat were solubilized (100 mm Tris-HCl pH 8.6, 0.12% (w/v) deoxycholate, and 5% (v/v) glycerol), and non-soluble material was pelleted by centrifugation. The solubilized proteins were separated on a 4–12% bis-Tris Zoom gel (Invitrogen). The gel was sectioned into 2.5-mm slices, and these were homogenized in the solubilization buffer. After centrifugation, the supernatants were assayed for lipase activities. Other Assays—The following marker enzymes were assayed: cytochrome c oxidase for mitochondrial inner membrane and antimycin A- and KCN-insensitive NADH cytochrome c reductase for endoplasmic reticulum (24Widell S. Larsson C. Larsson C. Moller I.M. The Plant Plasma Membrane. Springer Verlag, Berlin1990: 16-43Crossref Google Scholar), latent IDPase for Golgi membranes (essentially according to Ref. 25Sandelius A.S. Penel C. Auderset G. Brightman A. Millard M. Morré D.J. Plant Physiol. 1986; 81: 177-185Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), 1,3-β-glucan synthase for plasma membrane (26Fredrikson K. Larsson C. Physiol. Plant. 1989; 77: 196-201Crossref Scopus (53) Google Scholar), and monogalactosyldiacylglycerol (MGDG) synthase for chloroplast envelope (27Kjellberg J.M. Trimborn M. Andersson M. Sandelius A.S. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2000; 1485: 100-110Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). To analyze the sugar composition of DGDG, the isolated lipid was hydrolyzed in 2 m trifluoroacetic acid, reduced with sodium borohydride, and peracetylated. The resulting alditol acetates were analyzed by capillary gas chromatography on a DB-17 column (28Holm M. Månsson J.-E. Vanier M.-T. Svennerholm L. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1972; 280: 356-364Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar). The differences in lipid composition between different treatments were analyzed by one-way analysis of variance using the SPSS statistics software package for Windows (SPSS, Chicago, IL). Effects of Phosphate Limitation on the Lipid Composition of Oat Root Plasma Membranes—The lipid composition of root plasma membranes isolated from 2- and 4-week-old oat grown with or without phosphate is shown in Table I. In 4-week-old well-fertilized oat, glycerolipids made up 49% of the root plasma membrane lipids, whereas this proportion decreased to 41% in the phosphate-limited oat. As in the previous investigation (9Andersson M.X. Stridh M.H. Larsson K.E. Liljenberg C. Sandelius A.S. FEBS Lett. 2003; 537: 128-132Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar), cultivation without phosphate caused a marked decrease in the proportion of phospholipids concomitant with an increase in DGDG in the plasma membrane. This alteration was observed already 2 weeks after cultivation. After 4 weeks of cultivation, there were also significant increases in the proportions of sterol glucosides (SGs) and glucocylceramides (GlcCers) in plasma membranes isolated from the roots of phosphate-limited oat, compared with well-fertilized oat. The proportions of acylated SGs and free sterols remained unaltered, although the composition of free sterols was altered. The proportion of the major sterol, stigmasterol, decreased, whereas that of β-sitosterol increased in the phosphate-limited material (Table II). The phospholipid compositions were essentially as previously reported (9Andersson M.X. Stridh M.H. Larsson K.E. Liljenberg C. Sandelius A.S. FEBS Lett. 2003; 537: 128-132Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar), and after 4 weeks of cultivation, the decrease caused by phosphate starvation affected all phospholipid classes to approximately the same extent (data not shown).
